repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

body:
Related to #5040

> **Note**: #5371 needs to be merged first.

comment_data.body:
1) "to allow Cython module to be implemented in C++ but callable in C."? Just a sentence to explain why you might do it.

2) I wonder if `-D` is the best way to do this. Could it be done with a compiler-independent distutils command
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -264,6 +264,11 @@ When running into an error it is required to add the corresponding operator::
         Example operator++(int)
         Example operator--(int)
 
+Public Declarations in C++
+==========================
+
+Public declaration in C++ mode are exported as C++ API in Cython 3. This behavior can be changed by
+setting export keyword using ``__PYX_EXTERN_C`` macro: ``-D__PYX_EXTERN_C=extern "C"``.

@@ -264,6 +264,11 @@ When running into an error it is required to add the corresponding operator::
         Example operator++(int)
         Example operator--(int)
 
+Public Declarations in C++
+==========================
+
+Public declaration in C++ mode are exported as C++ API in Cython 3. This behavior can be changed by
+setting export keyword using ``__PYX_EXTERN_C`` macro: ``-D__PYX_EXTERN_C=extern "C"``.

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
When a file is compiled as C++, its public functions are declared as C++ API (using ``extern "C++"``) by default.
This disallows to call the functions from C code.  If the functions are really meant as a plain C API,
the ``extern`` declaration needs to be manually specified by the user.
This can be done by setting the ``CYTHON_EXTERN_C`` C macro to ``extern "C"`` during the compilation of the generated C++ file::
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -496,6 +496,29 @@ file consists of the full dotted name of the module, e.g. a module called
     the resulting ``.so`` file like a dynamic library.
     Beware that this is not portable, so it should be avoided.
 
+C++ public declarations
+^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^^
+
+When a file is compiled as C++, the public function is declared as C++ API (using ``extern "C++"``) by default. This disallows to call
+the function from C code. To declare the function as C API, the ``extern`` declaration needs to be manually specified by the user.
+This can be done by setting ``CYTHON_EXTERN_C`` C macro to ``extern "C"`` during compilation of generated C++ file::

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
Public declarations in C++ mode are exported as C++ API in Cython 3, using ``extern "C++"``.
This behaviour can be changed by setting the export keyword using the ``CYTHON_EXTERN_C`` macro
to allow Cython modules to be implemented in C++ but callable from C.
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -264,6 +264,12 @@ When running into an error it is required to add the corresponding operator::
         Example operator++(int)
         Example operator--(int)
 
+Public Declarations in C++
+==========================
+
+Public declaration in C++ mode are exported as C++ API in Cython 3. This behavior can be changed by
+setting export keyword using ``CYTHON_EXTERN_C`` macro to allow Cython module to be implemented in C++
+but callable in C.
